awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Award: Targeted Infusion Project: Advancing STEM Education Through Transportation Studies (TIP-ASETTS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing the research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering, and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NCA&T) intends to create a digital badging program for students interested in the transportation industry. The proposed work has the potential to increase student skillsets to increase competitiveness for technical opportunities in the transportation industry and increase diversity in the transportation field. It is the intent to position the proposed work in the P21 framework which focuses on equipping students with the skills they need to succeed in school and their careers in the 21st century.

The goal of the Advancing STEM Education Through Transportation Studies (ASETTS) digital badge program is to advance knowledge and understanding within STEM education through activities designed to increase the number of highly skilled NCA&T undergraduate students entering the transportation workforce. This goal will be achieved by using the following approach: (a) creating a stackable-units digital badge program that encourages undergraduate students to increase their skillsets along various dimensions such as life/career, innovation, technology, and core subject matter skills; (b) increasing the number of undergraduate students participating in transportation research experiences and other engaging activities that will expose students to career opportunities in transportation; (c) establishing a professional-to-student and student-to-student mentorship program, and (d) updating current courses by including activities designed to develop specific competencies needed in the transportation workforce. A successfully implemented program has the potential to serve as a case study through which the ability of a stackable-units digital badge program to increase students’ engagement in educational activities will be evaluated. By focusing on students across different STEM majors, the proposed program will be unique and novel in that it will develop students’ competitive skillsets such as initiative and self-direction as well as introduce them to transportation innovations and technologies. The research projects intend to cover diverse topic areas within the transportation domain including transportation demand management, optimization, emerging technologies, and human factors. Finally, through the integration of the P21 and experiential learning components in transportation courses along with the mentorship activities, the ASETTS program aims to innovate existing curricula and provide a much-needed support network to facilitate the success of students underrepresented in STEM disciplines who desire a career in the transportation industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University

por.por_cntn:
HBCU-UP TIP-ASETTS: Advancing Stem Education Through Transportation Studies

Project Outcomes Report (POR)

 

The ASETTS (Advancing STEM Education Through Transportation Studies) program at North Carolina A&T State University is an innovative initiative aimed at enhancing STEM education and increasing the number of skilled graduates entering the transportation workforce. With studies showing that 65% of students who pursue STEM degrees don't complete them within 6 years[1]—and even higher attrition rates for minority students—ASETTS provides a targeted solution. The program has demonstrated success in retaining underrepresented students in transportation careers, with various participants securing transportation industry positions in just the past year.

Enhancing Education and Engagement

One of the primary goals of the ASETTS program is to augment the educational experience of undergraduate students. The program revolutionized student engagement through an experiential learning framework and stackable credentials system, making participation flexible for working students and those with demanding schedules. This innovative approach led to remarkable growth, with student participation increasing from 69 activity completions in the first year to 208 by the third year. The stackable digital badge system allowed students to accumulate credentials at their own pace, with 97 completions in transportation core skills and 52 in transportation awareness activities, providing tangible evidence of their growing expertise.

Professional Development Opportunities

The ASETTS program has provided numerous professional development opportunities for students. Over the course of the project, 13 undergraduate researchers received comprehensive training in transportation research, from modeling to literature review. Additionally, students attended prestigious international conferences like the Transportation Research Board (TRB) annual meeting and key local conferences such as the Annual Meeting of the North Carolina Section of the Institute of Transportation Engineers, where they were exposed to industry leaders and networking opportunities, and several secured job offers through direct networking with local employers. Such experiences have proved invaluable as they prepare students for successful careers in transportation and related fields.

Recognition and Impact

The program's innovative approach has garnered recognition, including the Suitable Innovator Award at the Pathways 2023 Student Success conference. This accolade highlights the program's unique ability to bridge disciplines, connecting the Deese College of Business and Economics with the College of Engineering. Students worked on diverse projects including studying the impact of suburban sprawl, assessing revenue implications of transitioning from gas tax to mileage-based tax systems, and designing control methods for routing under real-time information. This interdisciplinary approach led to notable achievements, with four students being named TRB Minority Fellows and multiple students receiving prestigious scholarships from organization such as the Women in Transportation Seminar.

Community and Societal Benefits

The impact of the ASETTS program extends beyond the university. With research showing that Black students are twice as likely to leave STEM majors compared to their peers, ASETTS's 37% engagement rate and successful retention of underrepresented students in transportation disciplines represents a significant achievement. Through partnerships with initiatives like the HBCU Smart Cities Challenge, five ASETTS students developed practical solutions for North Carolina cities, aligning with local priorities such as Greensboro's 2040 Comprehensive Plan[2] goals for sustainable and equitable transportation. The program's structure is adaptable, allowing it to be applied to non-STEM disciplines as well, enhancing critical thinking and problem-solving skills among students across the university.

Future Prospects

The program's integration into the Region 4 University Transportation Center (UTC) ensures its sustainability and enables expansion to other universities in the southeastern United States. By investing in the education and training of future transportation professionals, the ASETTS program contributes to a more sustainable, efficient, and equitable transportation system, ultimately benefiting society as a whole.

In conclusion, as the transportation industry undergoes rapid transformation with artificial intelligence, connected vehicles, and smart infrastructure, the need for professionals with interdisciplinary skills becomes increasingly critical. The ASETTS program's success in bridging engineering, transportation science, and supply-chain/business perspectives positions its graduates to tackle these emerging challenges. Through its proven model of experiential learning and industry engagement, ASETTS creates a pipeline of diverse, technically skilled professionals ready to shape the future of transportation in a technology-driven world.


[1]Museus, S.D., et al., Racial and Ethnic Minority Student Success in STEM Education: ASHE Higher Education Report, Volume 36, Number 6. 2011: John Wiley & Sons.

[2] https://online.encodeplus.com/regs/greensboro-nc-comp/index.aspx (Last accessed November 1, 2024)


Last Modified: 11/04/2024
Modified by: Maranda E Mcbride
